item.title: Greek Architectures of Data Processing
item.description: Greeks are famous from many things. But first of the thing that comes in the mind when we hear “Greek” is the “Greek Architecture” and “Greek Alphabets” (i.

item.title: Processing Real-time streams in Databricks – Part 2
item.description: The first part of this post can be found Processing Real-Time Streams in Databricks – Part 1 This is the continuation of the part one, so we will not talk about the architecture and setup that is discussed in part 1.

item.title: Processing Real-Time Streams in Databricks – Part 1
item.description: Databricks is becoming the new normal in data processing technologies in cloud, both Azure and AWS. I wanted to create this post on step by step guide to get started on Realtime (streaming) analytics using spark streaming on Databricks

item.title: Introduction to Delta Architecture
item.description: In my previous blogs I have introduced Kappa and Lambda Architectures. These architectures are big data architectures and designed to support massive amounts of data both in real time and at rest.

item.title: How to structure the Data Lake
item.description: Data lake is framework/ concept/ guidance on where to place the data (except Microsoft named their product as Azure Data Lake). From technology point of view, it suggests to store all the data in object oriented or hierarchical storage.

item.title: Lambda Architecture using Databricks
item.description: From technology point of view Databricks is becoming the new normal in data processing technologies, in both Azure and AWS. This post provides a view of lambda architecture and uses Databricks at front and center.

item.title: 5 Things to get best out of Azure Databricks
item.description: Most of the customers I talk to are directly of indirectly asking to to scale their workloads and use Databricks. It has become the new normal in the data processing in cloud.

item.title: Introduction to Distributed Computing
item.description: Distributed computing technology enables the compute load to be spread, or distributed, across multiple nodes (computers) connected via a network. The networked machines connected to each other share the same goal and share the compute load to effectively collaborate and provide the resources to obtain the goal.
